qas.question: Why can't some memories be held onto forever?

answers.text: The storage in sensory memory and short-term memory generally has a strictly limited capacity and duration

qas.question: If a memory that is stored in with long term-memories, how long can you possibly rememeber it?
What is the capacity of long term memory?
If you knew a telephone number one week ago, but have forgotten it now, where was this memory stored?
By storing smaller quantities of info, long-term memory has this length of duration?
Short term memory can remember telephone numbers for many years though what?
Repetition allows short-term memory to remember what?
How many years can short-term memory be stored?

context: <a0_0>The storage in sensory memory and short-term memory generally has a strictly limited capacity and duration<a0_0/>, which means that information is not retained indefinitely. By contrast, long-term memory can store much larger quantities of information for potentially <b4_0>unlimited<b4_0/> duration (<a1_0>sometimes a whole life span)<a1_0/>. Its <a2_0><b8_0>capacity<b8_0/> is immeasurable<a2_0/>. For example, given a random seven-digit number we may remember it for only a few seconds before forgetting, suggesting it was stored <a3_0>in our short-term memory<a3_0/>. On the other hand, we can remember <b6_0>telephone numbers<b6_0/> for <b7_0>many years<b7_0/> through <b5_0>repetition<b5_0/>; this information is said to be stored in long-term memory.
